question: Question_06_(b)
statement:
Use part (a) to determine an approximation of the following definite
integral

\begin{align*}\int_0^{0.1} \frac{1}{1+x^3}dx\end{align*} so that the error in the
approximation satisfies

\begin{align*}|\text{error}| \leq 10^{-9}\end{align*} Remember to justify your answer.
sols:
We saw from
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH101/April 2011/Question 6 (a)}{part
a)} that we have the series expansion

\begin{align*}\frac{1}{1+x^3}=1-x^3+x^6-x^9+\ldots\end{align*} and so we can write that

\begin{align*}\int_0^{0.1} \frac{1}{1+x^3}\,dx &= \int_0^{0.1} dx - \int_0^{0.1} x^3\,dx +\int_0^{0.1} x^6\,dx - \int_0^{0.1} x^9\,dx +\ldots\\
&= 0.1 - \frac{(0.1)^4}{4} + \frac{(0.1)^7}{7} - \frac{(0.1)^{10}}{10} + \ldots\end{align*}
where the \emph{n}\textsuperscript{th} term is

\begin{align*}\frac{(-1)^n(0.1)^{3n+1}}{3n+1}\end{align*} Since this is an alternating
sequence which converges to zero, we have that the error when neglecting
everything past the \emph{n}\textsuperscript{th} term. Thus

\begin{align*}|\textrm{error}| &\leq \left| \frac{(-1)^n(0.1)^{3n+1}}{3n+1} \right| \\&= \frac{0.1^{3n+1}}{3n+1} \\&= \frac{10^{-(3n+1)}}{3n+1}\end{align*}
if we want this to be less than 10\textsuperscript{-9}, then we can
choose \emph{n} = 3, where the error will be less than

\begin{align*}\frac{10^{(-9+1)}}{9+1}=10^{-11}\end{align*} which works fine since it is
clearly even less than 10\textsuperscript{-9}.
hints: With a convergent power series, you can integrate term by term.

For an alternating series, the error is less than or equal to the
absolute value of the first neglected term.
